Situation1: Pre-dawn traffic is sparse and holding patterns are empty.
Situation2: Medical advice suggests this may be their final opportunity to travel long distances.
Story: The control room is quiet, the pre-dawn sky outside just beginning to lighten. My screens show only a handful of blips—no congestion, no emergencies, just the steady hum of routine. I lean back, but my mind is far from calm. The Hajj season is approaching, and my doctor’s words echo in my ears: “If you want to go, this year is your best chance.” My health is unpredictable, and the pilgrimage is a pillar of my faith, something I’ve dreamed of since childhood. But the schedule is tight, and my supervisor has already hinted at the need for all hands on deck, even during the quieter shifts. I know the expectation: keep the airspace safe, be present, be vigilant. Yet, my heart aches at the thought of missing Hajj, perhaps forever. I stare at the radar, feeling the weight of duty and devotion pressing in from both sides, unsure which call I will answer.
